quiz_metadata.title: Unit Testing in Python
quiz_metadata.description: This quiz covers the basics of unit testing in Python, including why unit testing is important, how to write unit tests, and best practices for unit testing.

questions.question_text: What is the primary purpose of unit testing?

options.text: To catch bugs early and ensure code quality

questions.explanation: Unit testing is primarily used to catch bugs early and ensure that code is working as expected, which is mentioned at timestamp [00:51].

questions.question_text: What is an example of a reason why we want to unit test?
questions.explanation: Enabling confident refactoring is one of the reasons why we want to unit test, which is mentioned at timestamp [01:06].

questions.question_text: What is the name of the Python testing framework mentioned in the video?
questions.explanation: The video mentions Pytest as the Python testing framework, which is mentioned at timestamp [03:39].

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the 'assert' statement in Pytest?
questions.explanation: The 'assert' statement is used to verify expected behavior, which is mentioned at timestamp [04:26].

questions.question_text: What is the command to run all tests in Pytest?
questions.explanation: The command to run all tests in Pytest is simply 'pytest', which is mentioned at timestamp [05:08].

questions.question_text: What is a best practice for writing unit tests?

options.text: Test only one thing per test

questions.explanation: Testing only one thing per test is a best practice, which is mentioned at timestamp [05:46].

questions.question_text: Why is it important to test edge cases?

options.text: To ensure code works correctly for normal cases
To ensure code works correctly for edge cases

questions.explanation: Testing edge cases is important to ensure that code works correctly for unexpected or unusual inputs, which is mentioned at timestamp [03:03].

questions.question_text: What should you do before submitting any code?

options.text: Run the tests to make sure the code is working
Don't run the tests, just submit the code
Run the tests, but only for normal cases
Run the tests, but only for edge cases

questions.explanation: You should run the tests to make sure the code is working before submitting it, which is mentioned at timestamp [07:04].

questions.question_text: What should you avoid when writing unit tests?
questions.explanation: You should avoid testing library code, as it has already been tested, which is mentioned at timestamp [07:12].

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of using descriptive test names?

options.text: To make the tests more difficult to understand
To make the tests more efficient
To make the tests more descriptive and easier to understand
To make the tests more vague

questions.explanation: Using descriptive test names makes the tests more descriptive and easier to understand, which is mentioned at timestamp [06:34].
